name: (2E)-1,3-benzothiazol-2-yl[(3-fluorophenyl)hydrazono]ethanenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1075

name: (2E)-1,3-benzothiazol-2-yl[(3-fluorophenyl)hydrazono]ethanenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1075
Reason:
The compound, (2E)-1,3-benzothiazol-2-yl[(3-fluorophenyl)hydrazono]ethanenitrile, has multiple functional groups that influence its melting point. The basic unit we can consider is benzothiazole, which has a typical melting point at around 98°C. Each functional group will either increase or decrease the melting point based on its characteristics:

1. The additional phenyl group linked with a hydrazone bond (―N=NH―) will increase the melting point due to the extension of the conjugated system and additional aromaticity. Let us assign an increase of approximately +40°C.

2. The fluorine substitution on the phenyl ring increases the melting point due to the strong electronegativity and the inductive effect, which enhances intermolecular forces. This effect might contribute an additional +20°C.

3. The nitrile group (―C#N) is a strong linear electron-withdrawing group, which will increase polarity, dipole moment, and subsequently the melting point. Let us assign a +30°C for this effect.

Adding these increments to the base melting point of benzothiazole gives us an approximate predicted melting point for the compound.
